Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Multicultural identity integration and conflict resolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
According to the 2010 U.S. Census, about 40 million people in the United States are foreign-born. Moreover, recent globalization is not a uniquely American phenomenon; the number of people living with multiple cultural identities has greatly increased across the globe. As a result, an increasing number of individuals persistently face the challenge of navigating between multiple cultural identities. This research will focus on how individuals negotiate their multiple identities. This project will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Ying-yi Hong, one of the eminent scholars in the field of multicultural identity, at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. Singapore is considered one of the most multicultural nations in the world, and thus an ideal location for studying multicultural identity.

This research will measure how cognitive styles facilitate integration of multiple cultural identities and how people manage conflicts between identities. In Study 1, participants will complete a task that measures ability to resolve conflict, as well as self-reported measures of multicultural identity integration. The relationship between these two measures will be tested. In Study 2, the relationship between multicultural identity integration and the resolution of intrapersonal (role) conflicts will be measured. In this study, participants will be presented with a series of hypothetical role conflicts and asked to generate solutions to these conflicts. For example, a working student may be presented with the conflict of staying late at work or going home to study for finals. The influence of an individual's cultural identity integration on their solutions will be measured. Finally, both studies will investigate whether participants' impressions of certain characteristics of Singapore influence how they adapt to the culture. In conclusion, this research seeks to gain a deeper understanding of the underlying mechanisms and outcomes of multicultural identity integration and how these processes are moderated by perceptions of the cultural context. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As immigration becomes more prevalent globally, an increasing number of individuals persistently face the challenge of navigating between multiple cultural identities. This research focused on how individuals negotiate their multiple identities and how that is related to conflict adaptation. This project was conducted in collaboration with Dr. Ying-yi Hong, one of the eminent scholars in the field of multicultural identity, at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore. Singapore is considered one of the most multicultural nations in the world, and thus an ideal location for studying multicultural identity. 

In this research, we measured how cognitive styles facilitate integration of multiple cultural identities and how people manage conflicts between identities. Participants completed a task adapted from cognitive psychology that measures ability to adapt to cognitive conflict.  Additionally, participants completed self-reported measures of identity integration. We observed a positive relationship between identity integration and conflict adaptation.  In other words, individuals who report their identities as being more integrated (vs. separated) demonstrate better conflict adaptation.  Additionally, individuals who view their cultural identities as more overlapping are more tolerant of another person with an opposing viewpoint.  In this part of the study, participants were presented with a hypothetical role conflict and then asked to rate another person who chose a different solution to the conflict.  Individuals who report their own identities as being more integrated rated this other person more positively, despite the fact that the other person had chosen a conflicting solution.  This research has implications for gaining a deeper understanding of the underlying mechanisms and outcomes of multicultural identity integration.  Additionally, these findings provide insight for how the processes underlying multicultural identity are related to interactions with others.  Finally, the findings from this research can be used to improve identity integration, conflict adaptation, and tolerance, and hopefully take steps towards improving the lives of immigrants around the world.  This NSF EAPSI award was funded in collaboration with the National Research Foundation of Singapore.
